title: Hong Kong protesters stand ground ahead of Chinese national day | World news | The Guardian
summary: cy leung digs in , demands protests cease `` immediately ''
protesters stockpile supplies , prepare for possible crackdown ahead of national holiday on wednesday .
hong kong protests : 'we hope it will continue until at least 1 october '

text: it 's just gone 2pm in hong kong , where protestors continue to hold key areas of the city in the fifth consecutive day of civil unrest .
my colleague tania branigan has just filed this dispatch : hong kong 's chief executive calls for protests to end , resisting calls to quit . ''
hong kong 's chief executive , leung chun-ying , urged protest leaders to immediately withdraw demonstrators from the centre of the city on tuesday , as they continued to call for his resignation .
thousands remained scattered across admiralty , causeway bay and mongkok .
the organising group occupy central with love and peace hascalled for people to maintain the momentum of the protests into wednesday 's national holiday .
numbers dwindled overnight - after peaking in the tens of thousands - but by lunchtime on tuesday more were arriving at the scene again .
some said they were protesting in shifts '' , giving friends time to go home and rest before returning .
others took the opportunity of thinner numbers in the early morning to clean the roads .
read the full story here i 'll be wrapping up our live blog now , but expect another to begin soon as the heat in hong kong cools and protesters who left to sleep or work return to the streets .
here 's where we leave things : thousands of pro-democracy protesters remain in the streets of downtown hong kong on tuesday afternoon local time .
monday 's enormous crowds have subsided , but are expected to swell again this evening ahead of a public holiday on wednesday for china 's national day .
a map of protest sites is here .
protestors are stockpiling supplies and erecting makeshift barricades , fearing that authorities might crack down on the protests before wednesday 's public holiday .
hong kong 's embattled chief executive leung chun-ying has called on protest organisations to immediately '' withdraw their supporters from the streets .

he has maintained that the people 's liberation army will not intervene to end the demonstrations , but said the illegal '' protests will not change beijing 's decision to vet hong kong leadership candidates .
protest organizer benny tai has acknowledged that occupy central had incomplete control over the movement .
since the protests began , 41 people have been wounded , including police , and 78 arrested , according to officials .
police have used pepper spray and tear gas and displayed weapons .
protesters are calling for democracy for hong kong .
their demands include the ouster of chief executive cy leung and open elections in 2017 .
since 1997 hong kong has operated under a one country , two party '' policy with china .
but an announcement last month of new elections restrictions for 2017 fueled concern that beijing was seeking to erode the policy .
the chinese government still has a few options , '' writes ying chan in comment is free .
these include sacrificing leung - or sending in the army .
read more here .

according to this opinion poll just published by hong kong university , chief executive cy leung 's popularity rating hit negative 35 points in the days before these protests broke out last week , a figure the pollsters said indicated a credibility crisis '' for the leader .

interestingly , the poll found that public support for the way the hong kong government managed its relationship with the chinese government had sunk to the worst figure since july 1997 '' - largely reflecting beijing 's push to vet hong kong leadership candidates .
the hong kong pharmacists ' union has sent this open letter to hong kong 's chief executive cy leung , asking that the police avoid the use of pepper spray and tear gas to disperse protests .

we fully understand that the hong kong police force would need to disperse the mass of protestors occupying certain public areas but in the best interests of young children and infants , pregnant women , the elderly , and chronically ill individuals which may happen to be crossing the public area and also the residents living in the area , the use of irritating chemicals found in tear gas and pepper spray may cause health hazards to harm many innocent people as well as unprepared protestors , '' it says .
patrick boehler ( @ mrbaopanrui ) hong kong pharmacists union urges the police not to use tear gas .

documents.title: cy leung digs in , demands protests cease `` immediately ''
text: here 's a report over the wires of the earlier press conference by hong kong 's chief executive , leung chun-ying .
his resignation is a key demand of many of the protestors .

hong kong 's chief executive leung chun-ying tuesday called on protest leaders to immediately '' withdraw their followers from the streets in his first public comments since demonstrators were tear gassed by police .
occupy central founders had said repeatedly that if the movement is getting out of control , they would call for it to stop .
i 'm now asking them to fulfil the promise they made to society , and stop this campaign immediately , '' leung said .
occupy central is the main grassroots group behind the last two days of street protests .
a number of student groups who are separate from occupy are also spearheading the campaign for genuine democracy in the former british colony .
however occupy rejected leung 's demands and renewed its calls for him to step down .

if leung chun-ying announces his resignation , this occupation will be at least temporarily stopped in a short period of time , and we will decide on the next move , '' co-founder chan kin-man told reporters after leung 's comments .
this would be a very important signal , then at least we know the government has changed their attitude and wants to solve this crisis , '' he said .
chief executive leung chun-ying gestures during a press conference after his 2014 policy address in hong kong on january 15 , 2014 .
afp photo / philippe lopezphilippe lopez/afp/getty images lopez/afp/getty images
twitter has produced this interactive chart showing the extraordinary reaction to these protests on its social network .
activity peaked at 12 tweets per second on sunday , with around 1.3m tweets sent in the past four days .
it 's also put together the most-tweeted images from the unprecedented five-day campaign :

the south china morning post says it has obtained this email sent from the city 's police commissioner to all officers this morning : message from the commissioner of police during the recent unlawful assembly at the central government complex and its vicinity , the enforcement actions taken by the force have attracted some controversies .
the senior management fully understand the difficulty of the task , and the complexity of this unprecedented operation .
in this very trying situation , you have remained steadfast , demonstrated extreme patience and performed your duties in the most professional manner throughout the operation .
your unreserved efforts in serving the community in this critical moment are much appreciated by the senior management .
i trust we will stay united , remain resolute , and overcome this challenging situation together .
thank you .
if you 're just catching up with this story and prefer your news in cartoon form , here 's a animated explainer produced by hong kong 's passionately anti-beijing apple daily :

the markets are watching the events in hong kong cautiously , wondering , like many , how china will react to the continuing civil disobedience on the streets : asian markets were in hesitant mood on tuesday as investors wondered what china 's response would be to civil unrest in hong kong , while the u.s. dollar was on track to post its biggest monthly gain in well over a year .
tens of thousands of pro-democracy protesters blocked hong kong streets on tuesday , in one of the biggest political challenges to beijing since the tiananmen square crackdown 25 years ago .
the unrest was an added complication for investors amid long-standing concerns about the health of china 's economy .
an hsbc survey of manufacturing ( pmi ) for september disappointed slightly by showing a final reading of 50.2 , steady on august but down from its preliminary 50.5 .
one bright spot was a measure of new export orders which climbed to a 4-1/2-year-high of 54.5 .
the official version of the pmi is due on wednesday and analysts look for a steady outcome around 51.0 .
hong kong 's hang seng index shed another 0.9 percent to its lowest in three months .
msci 's broadest index of asia-pacific shares outside japan lost 0.5 percent having already fallen sharply on monday .
chinese shares have been less troubled , perhaps because news and images of the protests are hard to come by on the mainland .
the shanghai index was flat near a 19-month peak while the csi300 held steady .
enda curran ( @ endacurran ) hong kong 's central bank says 37 branches or offices of 21 banks have been affected and closed by the protests .
this incredible time-lapse footage ( via the south china morning post ) shows how causeway bay was filled yesterday .
timelapse footage from causeway bay

this statement has just come through from the chinese , new york-based ngo , human rights in china : in 1989 , millions of democracy and labor activists and other citizens throughout china demanded reforms .
the leaders responded with tanks and violence and then attempted to silence demands for political reform with the benefits of economic liberalization .
what the chinese people got are unsustainable and inequitable development , growing social conflicts , and massive environmental and human costs .
today , 25 years later , the people of hong kong are standing up and demanding that beijing deliver on its one country , two systems '' promises .

they are rejecting the august 31 , 2014 decision of the national people 's congress standing committee on the selection '' of the chief executive , which requires candidates to be endorsed by a majority of a beijing-controlled nominating committee .

in the face of threats and beijing 's hardline stance , the students , supported by hong kong labor unions and the public , have resorted to civil disobedience with developments still unfolding , one thing is clear : the people of hong kong have already succeeded in putting a spotlight on the anti-democratic nature of the current regime .
leaders in beijing now face a historic test and a historic opportunity to advance genuine social stability and democracy in hong kong .
will they make the same tragic mistake again or demonstrate true leadership by listening to the voices of the people ?
a useful visual breakdown of the spread of these protests from the wall street journal .
breakdown of hong kong protests street journal
hong kong 's embattled chief executive leung chun-ying has just given a press conference in the city .

here 's a taste of what he had to say : andrew peng ( @ theapjournalist ) # breaking : cy leung calls for # occupycentral to halt occupation of hong kong , says police are investigating yesterday 's mongkok car incident andrew peng ( @ theapjournalist ) cy leung : # occupycentral will continue for a long time , and the people hong kong will pay a price for the daily disturbances in their lives .
andrew peng ( @ theapjournalist ) # breaking : cy leung says the central government will not change its decision amid `` illegal '' # occupycentral protests .

# umbrellarevolution andrew peng ( @ theapjournalist ) cy leung says he will not seek assistance from the pla : `` i have full confidence in hk police ; they can handle our conflicts '' # occupycentral

documents.title: protesters stockpile supplies , prepare for possible crackdown ahead of national holiday on wednesday
text: here 's the latest update from reuters : tens of thousands of pro-democracy protesters extended a blockade of hong kong streets on tuesday , stockpiling supplies and erecting makeshift barricades ahead of what some fear may be a push by police to clear the roads before chinese national day .
riot police shot pepper spray and tear gas at protesters at the weekend but withdrew on monday to ease tension as the ranks of demonstrators swelled .
protesters spent the night sleeping or holding vigil unharassed on normally busy roads in the global financial hub .
throughout the night , rumours rippled through crowds of protesters that police were preparing to move in again .
as the sun rose many remained wary , especially on the eve of wednesday 's anniversary of the communist party 's foundation of the people 's republic of china in 1949 .
many powerful people from the mainland will come to hong kong .

the hong kong government wo n't want them to see this , so the police must do something , '' sui-ying cheng , 18 , a freshman at hong kong university 's school of professional and continuing education , said of the national day holiday .
we are not scared .
we will stay here tonight .
tonight is the most important , '' she said .

the protesters , mostly students , are demanding full democracy and have called on the city 's leader leung chun-ying to step down after beijing on aug. 31 ruled out free elections for hong kong 's leader , known as the chief executive , in 2017 .

china rules hong kong under a one country , two systems '' formula that accords the former british colony a degree of autonomy and freedoms not enjoyed in mainland china , with universal suffrage set as an eventual goal .

protesters massed in at least four of hong kong 's busiest areas , including admiralty , where hong kong 's government is headquartered , the central business district , causeway bay , one of the city 's most bustling shopping areas , and the densely populated mong kok district in kowloon .
organisers said as many as 80,000 people thronged the streets after the protests flared on friday night .
no independent estimate of numbers was available .
i must stress that the events happening now can not be attributed to the students or occupy central .
it has evolved into a civil movement , '' said alex chow , the leader of the hong kong federation of students .
protesters set up supply stations with water bottles , fruit , crackers , disposable raincoats , towels , goggles , face masks and tents , indicating they were in for the long haul .
some lugged metal road barricades into positions on the edge of crowds , presumably to slow a police advance .
in at least one location , several minivans and a truck were parked in rows in an apparent effort to block a road .
read the full report here kristie lu stout cnn ( @ klustout ) 'we do n't need any tear gas , we 're already crying . '
pic by @ twitterid # hongkong
some of the streets that were packed all through monday and overnight have begun to empty now , as protestors go home to rest or head to work .
austin ramzy ( @ austinramzy ) view from central towards admiralty .

heather timmons ( @ heathat ) last night 's crowds now at work , leaving an empty gloucester rd near wanchai # occupyhongkong fion li ( @ fion li ) chater road as morning comes # occupycentral organisers say they expect the crowd to swell again on wednesday and thursday , a public holiday in hong kong to celebrate china 's national day on 1 october .
the china media project at the university of hong kong has this run-down on how the umbrella revolution '' protests are being covered in mainland china .
it notes that a lot of press is simply ignoring the events in hong kong , but around 20 papers have up xinhua 's report of a statement by chinese authorities describing the gatherings as illegal '' .
one state-run paper , the global times , has put the protests on its front page , its headline reading : hong kong government fiercely rejects illegal 'occupy central . ' ''
front page of the state-owned global times media project there 's also a sample of some of the posts being deleted from the chinese social network weibo as quickly as they appear '' .

interestingly , the deleted posts include those critical of the protestors , such as this one : a deleted weibo post criticising hong kong protestors media project meanwhile , here 's a taste of why these demonstrations have been tagged the umbrella revolution : tom grundy ( @ tomgrundy ) once used to shield them from tear gas , umbrellas now protect # occupycentral protesters from the sun .
here 's the wall street journal 's live video feed from hong kong .

wsj reporter thomas di fonzo is currently walking through the protest sites interviewing the remaining demonstrators , many of who are sprawled out on the street sleeping or reading newspaper coverage of yesterday 's dramatic events .
they 're not the only ones getting rest where they can : take the square ( @ takethesquare ) # occupycentral , that headache for # hongkong police .
great photo by @ twitterid

a former professor in beijing , patrick chovanec , posted this sobering image to twitter earlier , taken at the height of the 1989 tiananmen square protests , the last time the chinese government grappled with a political challenge as significant as the protests of the last few days .

patrick chovanec ( @ prchovanec ) there was a moment like this in 1989 , when it felt like people power might prevail meanwhile , if you 're reading from hong kong , please consider sharing your images , videos and stories with us via guardian witness .
there are a number of excellent contributions on the site already .

tom grundy on the ground writes that students are pleading '' with protesters who have spent the night on the streets to hang around until 8am hong kong time ( which we 've just hit ) , when reinforcements will arrive .
tom grundy ( @ tomgrundy ) more students pleading with protesters to remain till 8am 'shift ' takes over .
# occupycentral admiralty .
nonetheless , he says , the crowds appear to be dispersing .
tom grundy ( @ tomgrundy ) # occupycentral crowds dissipating but momentum wo n't .
wed & thur are public holidays , more will likely join protests .
organisers have said they 're hoping the demonstrations continue until at least wednesday , 1 october , china 's national day .
we hope it will continue until at least 1 october .
then we will announce new actions .
it is not realistic for people to occupy central forever , '' chan kinman , one of the founders of occupy central with peace and love , told my colleague tania branigan earlier .
we have to be careful not to invite a backlash .
any civil disobedience has to be proportionate and at a certain time we have got to stop . ''
my colleague tania branigan reported earlier on clashes between demonstrators and some hong kong residents angered by the way the protests have disrupted everyday life in the bustling city .
a vignette of how these clashes are playing out , from the harbour times : harbour times ( @ harbourtimes ) man shows up mad b/c his children ca n't go to school so he ca n't work .
leaves after getting free food # occupycwb # hk
tom grundy ( @ tomgrundy ) despite rumours of police moving in , # occupycentral peaceful in admiralty as sun rises .
some good background from the new york times on what 's sparked this latest , and largest , round of demonstrations : beijing 's proposed changes to hong kong 's mini-constitution , the basic law .

here 's the key info : article 45 of the law , which was ratified in 1990 , states that hong kong 's top leader , the chief executive , should eventually be chosen by universal suffrage upon nomination by a broadly representative nominating committee in accordance with democratic procedures . ''
the government in beijing has to approve of any decision made by hong kong voters , according to the basic law .
it goes on : in 2007 , the people 's congress ruled that in 2017 the chief executive could be chosen by universal suffrage the hitch : the broadly representative nominating committee . ''

on aug. 31 , the national people 's congress standing committee ruled that to appear on the ballot , candidates had to get more than half the votes of the nominating committee , which would be identical to the election committee that had previous chief executives .
to hong kong 's pro-democracy activists , this was unacceptable because it guaranteed that only candidates approved by beijing would be nominated .

read the full story here wrapped in plastic to shield from pepper spray , a student protester stands behind a makeshift barrier blocking main streets in the central business district of hong kong , late monday , sept. 29 , 2014 .
( ap photo/vincent yu ) yu/ap
this incredible video by hong kong student nero chan shows the enormous scale of monday 's demonstrations , from a camera attached to a drone flying above the city .
it 's nearing 7am in hong kong as pro-democracy demonstrations in the city enter their fifth day .

harbour times ( @ harbourtimes ) students are waking up from quite a peaceful night # occupycausewaybay # hk police have withdrawn from the areas swarming with protestors and by all reports the last few hours in the streets have been peaceful .
you can find our latest summary here .
follow our china correspondent tania branigan ( @ taniabranigan ) , who is on the scene in hong kong , and jonathan kaiman ( @ jrkaiman ) , in beijing .
i 'll be providing live updates throughout the next few hours .
get in touch at @ twitterid
there 's a les miserables theme in some corners of the protest , complete with singing : sarah clarke ( @ sarahclarkeabc ) 'do you hear the people sing ? '
pro-democracy sign hangs in front of hk govt building , & above demo # occupycentral
as our live blog coverage continues , here 's a summary of where things stand : thousands of pro-democracy protesters remained in the streets in downtown hong kong early tuesday morning local time .
the protests began last week and ballooned over the weekend .
an organizer of occupy central with peace and love , a main group behind the movement , said the group was asking crowds to stay through wednesday , 1 october , china 's national day .
a map of protest sites is here .
we hope it will continue until at least 1 october .
then we will announce new actions , '' said chan kinman of occupy central with peace and love .
we have to be careful not to invite a backlash .
any civil disobedience has to be proportionate and at a certain time we have got to stop . ''
protest organizer benny tai acknowledged that occupy central had incomplete control over the movement .
since the protests began , 41 people have been wounded , including police , and 78 arrested , according to officials .
police have used pepper spray and tear gas and displayed weapons .
protesters are calling for democracy for hong kong .
their demands include the ouster of chief executive cy leung and open elections in 2017 .
since 1997 hong kong has operated under a one country , two party '' policy with china .
but an announcement last month of new elections restrictions for 2017 fueled concern that beijing was seeking to erode the policy .
the chinese government still has a few options , '' writes ying chan in comment is free .
these include sacrificing leung - or sending in the army .
read more here .
read tania branigan 's latest dispatch from hong kong : more join protests as crowds are urged to keep going . ''
video : hong kong lit up by democracy march pro-democracy protesters in hong kong block one of the city 's main roads on monday , in what appears to be the largest demonstration yet .
tens of thousands of protesters light up hong kong with their smartphones and chant for hong kong 's chief executive , leung chun-ying , to step down
a vehicle drives among protesters blocking the main street to the financial central district , outside the government headquarters , in hong kong september 29 , 2014 .
barria/reuters
occupy central is tweeting updates from the south china morning post live blog of the protests : occupy central 和平佔中 ( @ oclphk ) scmp 's 4:14a update

the south china morning post reports that spyware is circulating online under the guise of a smartphone app claiming to coordinate the occupy central movement : the spyware is disguised as an application for android smartphones or tablets , code4hk , a group of coders trying to improve government transparency in hong kong , said .
eff ( @ eff ) fake occupy central app covertly installs malware on pro-democracy protestors ' cell phones in hong kong .

a university of hong kong poll that has tracked the public 's confidence in the one country , two systems '' policy shows that confidence hit an all-time low of 37.6 % this summer after peaking in 2007 at 74.9 % ( note : 2007 was the year the national people 's congress standing committee decided that hong kong could openly elect its chief executive in first-time elections in 2017 , a promise that now appears to be eroding ) .
vox has a chart tracking the number since the advent of the policy in 1997 , when confidence in the policy was at 57 % .

the most handy choice for china to calm the public is to have leung step down , '' a local political science professor tells bloomberg , referring to cy leung , the hong kong chief executive : the gatherings - spurred by china 's decision last month that candidates for a 2017 leadership election must be vetted - pose one of the biggest challenges president xi jinping has faced since he became head of the communist party two years ago .
china opposes the illegal gathering in hong kong and activities that damage the city 's stability , foreign ministry spokeswoman hua chunying said in a statement yesterday .
the ultimate call of people is true democracy but china would n't be willing to meet that , '' said ma ngok , an associate professor for political science at chinese university of hong kong .
the most handy choice for china to calm the public is to have leung step down .
it 's the most cost-effective way for china . ''
read the full piece here .
the local edition of china daily : city shut down on 2nd day of blockades : police withdraw riot gear as sit-ins appear peaceful . ''
beijing expresses confidence in chief executive . ''
andrew peng ( @ theapjournalist ) here 's how the hong kong edition of the pro-beijing china daily is covering the # occupyhk protests .
writing in comment is free , journalist and eduactor ying chan asks , so what is the end game ?
`` : the leung government has effectively lost control of the streets as the police force is outnumbered and outmanoeuvred .
in many neighbourhoods , groups of young men and women have built makeshift barricades at key intersections and entrances to the subway .
there were no police in sight to stop them .
[ ] yet the chinese government still has a few options .
it could send in the army , the pla , in the name of restoring public order and retaking the city 's streets .
president xi jinping 's tough stance towards political reform in hong kong is consistent with his record of tightening up ideological control on the mainland .
under xi , china has developed a master narrative that frames the democratic aspirations of hong kong as the work of evil foreign forces '' trying to undermine the sovereignty of china .
read the full piece here .

one key point that ying raises : nevertheless , on sunday , benny tai , one of the three key leaders of the occupy central movement , admitted that the group had lost control of the movement , at least for now '' : for the first time in hong kong 's history , hundreds of thousands of people are coordinating themselves with little direction from government or institutions .
it is a classic case of the unorganised coming together with the help of technology , as described by clay shirky in his book here comes everybody .
editorial : the guardian view on the battle for democracy in hong kong the chinese ca n't say they were n't warned .

everybody with even an ounce of common sense told beijing and its local satraps in hong kong that their transparent attempt to fix the election of the next chief executive of that territory by ensuring that only vetted candidates could stand was likely to blow up in their faces .
so it has proved , with police over the weekend battling student demonstrators whose admirable commitment to democracy seems to have surprised the government .
this is exactly the kind of image which a financial centre whose stability has until now been a byword does not need .
so far there has been no resort to lethal arms , and no mass detentions , but every day that goes by without dialogue increases the possibility of both .
how could the chinese authorities have got themselves into such a mess ?
the answer can already be discerned in the way pro-chinese media are describing the situation .
there the blame is laid on foreigners and western intelligence agencies .
there is stress on illegality '' and the culpability of citizens who do not love china '' .
there seems no room in the official mind for the idea that it has made the wrong decisions .
read the full piece here .

the white house is urging authorities in hong kong to show restraint with pro-democracy protesters , the associated press reports : white house press secretary josh earnest says the united states supports freedom of expression and peaceful assembly for the people of hong kong .
police have used tear gas and other methods to try to control the demonstrations that have paralyzed the city 's financial district .
the protesters are unhappy that beijing has rejected open nominations for candidates for the first-ever elections for hong kong 's leader , promised for 2017 .
earnest says the united states believes the legitimacy of the office will be enhanced if they are given a genuine choice of candidates . ''
earnest said hong kong needs an open society with the highest degree of autonomy .

in her latest report from hong kong , the guardian 's tania branigan ( @ taniabranigan ) notes the orderliness of the protesters : the demonstrators have been remarkably orderly ; one sign apologised for any inconvenience caused .
on sunday , protesters held their hands in the air each time they confronted police .
on monday , they handed out fresh fruit and crackers , collected rubbish and even fanned passers-by to keep them cool .
even so , organisers and participants know that hong kong remains a politically conservative society where many are concerned that protests could upset the economic stability of the financial hub .
the hong kong dollar and hong kong shares slipped on monday .
retired civil servant rose ha , 58 , told tania there was a clear generation gap : she had come to support the students , but few people of her age sympathised .
we are the odd ones out in our group .
[ the others ] enjoy what they have and do n't want things to be chaotic , '' she said .
our friends , who are maybe rich or in power , just denounce the actions and think the students have been misled , '' added her friend ben ho , 60 .
people who are older lose touch with younger generations .
they sit in restaurants and just criticise they think in hong kong you can enjoy freedom and a peaceful life ; why destroy it ?
what they ignore is that they are a privileged group and people are suffering from injustice and unfairness and the lack of opportunities . ''
read the full piece here .
why all the umbrellas ?

some have dubbed it the umbrella revolution '' - here 's the guardian 's john henley on how the umbrella became a symbol of the hong kong democracy protests '' : portable umbrellas , often turned inside out to provide better protection , were the main line of defence on sunday night for the huge crowds of protesters trying to push past barricades thrown up in the central financial district .
in between firing bursts of pepper spray from backpack sprayers , riot police seized and destroyed as many as they could .
umbrellas are stacked at the protest site for pro-democracy activists ' use if they need to shield themselves from pepper spray , monday , sept. 29 , 2014 in hong kong .

maye-e/ap so valuable are they to the protesters - not only against pepper spray but the blazing midday sun - that by monday morning , associated press was reporting that supporters had donated hundreds of replacements , which were being handed out to demonstrators who needed them at special distribution stations on the fringes of the protest zone .
read the full piece here .

deputy british prime minister nick clegg has tweeted in support of the protesters : nick clegg ( @ nick clegg ) i sympathise a great deal with the brave pro-democracy demonstrators taking to the streets of hong kong .
1/3 nick clegg ( @ nick clegg ) the uk remains committed to the joint declaration and the principle of 'one country , two systems ' .
2/3 nick clegg ( @ nick clegg ) universal suffrage must mean real choice for the people of hong kong and a proper stake in the 2017 election .
one of the main targets of the protesters ' ire is cy leung , the highly unpopular chief executive of hong kong .
occupy central and others have called for his ouster .
it will be quite difficult for beijing to withdraw its decision , '' said chan kinman , one of the founders of occupy central with peace and love .
but if we ask the chief executive to step down , and a new government replaces him , it opens a window for us to start the constitutional reform process over again .
that 's a more realistic tactic . ''
protesters gather in the streets outside the hong kong government complex next to a cardboard poster of c.y.leung , hong kong 's chief executive on september 30 , 2014 in hong kong .
bronstein/getty images

documents.title: hong kong protests : 'we hope it will continue until at least 1 october '
text: how long will the protests last ?
a protester 's sign in causeway bay , hong kong .
branigan we hope it will continue until at least 1 october .
then we will announce new actions .
it is not realistic for people to occupy central forever , '' chan kinman , one of the founders of occupy central with peace and love , told the guardian 's tania branigan .
we have to be careful not to invite a backlash .
any civil disobedience has to be proportionate and at a certain time we have got to stop . ''
pro-democracy protesters gather in the early hours of the morning on the streets around the government headquarters , tuesday , sept. 30 , 2014 , in hong kong .
maye-e/ap protesters sleep on the streets outside the hong kong government complex overnight on september 30 , 2014 in hong kong .
bronstein/getty images protesters gather in the streets outside the hong kong government complex on september 30 , 2014 in hong kong .
bronstein/getty images

here 's a map of key protest sites from the new york times : the new york times ( @ nytimes ) what you should know about the protests in hong kong the most persistent protest has been in admiralty on tim mei avenue near the central government offices ( map ) .
views of the scene monday night show protesters filling connaught road central .
smaller protests have sprung up in the shopping district of causeway bay and in mong kok , kowloon .
the guardian 's tania branigan has filed a new dispatch from hong kong , more join protests as crowds are urged to keep going '' .

fresh waves of pro-democracy protesters have swept in , '' she writes , and the mood was festive rather than angry '' : fresh waves of pro-democracy protesters have swept into the heart of hong kong , as a leader of the civil disobedience movement urged them to keep the momentum going until wednesday 's national holiday .
crowds blocked one of the city 's main roads on monday from the financial area of central to the bar district of wanchai in what appeared to be the largest demonstrations yet .
tens of thousands were packed so tightly into admiralty , around the government headquarters , that it was hard to move through the masses gathered beneath the skyscrapers .

some have dubbed it the umbrella revolution '' in reference to the umbrellas carried by protesters to ward off teargas or pepper spray attacks , and which also served to shelter them from the fierce sun earlier in the day .
with no sign of police force on monday evening , the mood was festive rather than angry .

participants held up their smartphones to create a glittering sea of lights and joined in a mass rendition of do you hear the people sing - the revolutionaries ' song from the musical les miserables .
many in the overwhelmingly young crowd wore black and sported yellow ribbons .
others had come straight from their offices in smart shirts ; two teenage convent girls were still in their starched white uniforms .
read the full piece here .

the hong kong protests is unique in part because of the exceptional technological savvy - and access to technology - of the participants , a local law professor tells tania bratigan ( @ taniabranigan ) : bryan druzin , a chinese university of hong kong law professor who 's been researching civil unrest in the age of social media , says hong kong is a fascinating case study : you could say its something comparable to the arab spring , but hong kong is unique because we 've never seen a city with such advanced use of internet , technology and social media engaging in social unrest .
practically everyone under 30 has a smartphone and internet penetration is about 70 per cent - i do n't think there was anything like that in tunisia or egypt .
and it is a very , very small city . ''
he suggested that without social media , protestors could not organise as easily , flexibly and dynamically '' as they are doing .
whatsapp , wechat , and firechat are all being widely used , as well as facebook and twitter .
read in the guardian : firechat - the messaging app that 's powering the hong kong protests . ''

pro-democracy protesters flash lights outside the hong kong government headquarters , on the second day of the mass civil disobedience campaign occupy hong kong , admiralty , hong kong , china , 29 september 2014 .
hofford/epa

the occupy central with love and peace twitter account @ twitterid circulates message from the group 's leadership , retweets photos and reports from protest scenes and helps coordinate protest action : occupy central 和平佔中 ( @ oclphk ) press release : oc condemns gov for ignoring ppl 's request for genuine universal suffrage , employing delay tactics

the most recent dispatch on the protests from the guardian 's tania branigan , reporting from the scene , notes that while the demonstrations have paralyzed daily life in parts of the city , it 's business as usual elsewhere : [ update : tania has filed a new dispatch , hong kong : more join protests as crowds are urged to keep going , '' here . ]

police attempts to use teargas to clear huge protests from admiralty and central in downtown hong kong late on sunday backfired , instead spurring more people to take to the streets , with numbers peaking in the tens of thousands .
new protests sprang up in causeway bay and mongkok , in kowloon .
what we have seen is spontaneous - without leadership , without prior organisation , of its own volition a people 's movement .
we simply want basic dignity .
we simply want to be respected , '' said lawmaker alan leong of the civic party .
parts of the financial hub , generally known for its orderliness , were paralysed by the protesters on monday .
banks , schools and some businesses were closed .
but in central , businesses operated as usual and in causeway bay , tourists and shoppers made their way around the demonstrations .

read the full report here , and follow tania on twitter for the latest from the protests as they unfold : tania branigan ( @ taniabranigan ) rt @ twitterid : a protester holding an umbrella with slogans urging the police to apologize for using tear gas
for basic background on the protests in hong kong , read our explanatory article published monday , under the umbrellas : what do hong kong 's protesters want from china ? ''
what do the protesters want ?
electoral freedom is the main demand .

this is a perennial concern in hong kong , and it has again come to a head after china announced that beijing would vet candidates to run in the 2017 elections , thus regulating the race to be hong kong chief executive .
protesters see the new rules as a sign that china may be seeking to erode the one country , two systems '' rubric in place in hong kong since 1997 , when it reverted from british to chinese control .
read the full piece here .
welcome to our live blog coverage of protests in hong kong , where it 's just after 3am and large pro-democracy demonstrations are entering their fifth day .
the protests began with a student strike last week and ballooned over the weekend with a call to action from the occupy central with love and peace movement .
attempts by police to disperse the protesters using tear gas and pepper spray have backfired .
crowds in downtown hong kong have been estimated in the tens of thousands , with some protesters claiming even larger numbers .
thousands remained in the streets in hong kong overnight from monday to tuesday , in at least two main locations .

the mood appears to be largely calm , although there has been at least one report of potential violence : shortly after midnight local time , a car ran into a crowd of protesters in mong kok , kowloon .
there were no reports of serious injuries in the incident .
( hong kong is eight hours ahead of gmt and 12 hours ahead of us eastern time . )
police in riot gear mostly withdrew from protest areas on monday after unleashing widely documented tear gas attacks sunday that failed to disperse crowds .
since the protests began , 41 people have been wounded , including police , and 78 arrested , according to officials .
the occupy central movement had planned a large sit-in to mark china 's national day on wednesday .
the protest began early , but there are ample signs of organization among protesters , including speeches by leadership , social networking , food service , and violins .
the guardian 's tania branigan ( @ taniabranigan ) has been reporting from the scene , and jonathan kaiman ( @ jrkaiman ) has been reporting from beijing .
join us for all the latest updates .

key_events.text:
5.19am BST
05:19
CY Leung digs in, demands protests cease "immediately"

2.52am BST
02:52
Protesters stockpile supplies, prepare for possible crackdown ahead of national holiday on Wednesday

8.54pm BST
20:54
Hong Kong protests: 'We hope it will continue until at least 1 October'

bulletin.text: Huge crowds subside but pro-democracy campaigners continue to hold key Hong Kong streets, preparing for renewed protests - and a possible crackdown - on Wednesday's national day holiday.
This blog has now ended: live updates continue here.
